His retainers came forward, assisted  him into his trappings, strapped on the translator. He sighed heavily,  adjusted the volume.

 "May hide-ticks devour the gougerforms!" Hoshick bellowed. "You've  given me such a sprong-ache as I'll remember each spawning-time for a  year."


 "Speaking of hide-ticks," said Retief, "we've developed a biterform—"


 "Enough!" Hoshick roared, so loudly that the translator bounced on his  hide. "Suddenly I yearn for the crowded yellow sands of Jaq. I had  hoped...." He broke off, drew a rasping breath. "I had hoped, Retief,"  he said, speaking sadly now, "to find a new land here where I might  plan my own Mosaic, till these alien sands and bring forth such a crop  of paradise-lichen as should glut the markets of a hundred worlds.  "But surely your spawn-fellows would never condone such an attitude."


 "My spawn-fellows aren't here. And besides, didn't I mention it? No  one who's really in the know would think of engaging in competition by  mere combat if there were any other way. Now, you mentioned tilling the  sand, raising lichens—things like that—"

 Hoshick curled his back in attention. "Retief, you're quite serious?  You would leave all the fair sand hills to us?"

 "We'll talk over the details later. I'm sure we can establish a set of  rules that will satisfy all parties. Now I've got to get back. I think  some of the gougerforms are waiting to see me."

    That “activity” is combat.  Not irrigation schemes or land surveys, but organizing battalions, pitting trained skirmishers against us, debating weapon rules, wagering on biterforms and gougerforms.  

2.  Their entire military buildup is a theatrical challenge, not a land-defense strategy.  They summon “a few hundred” warriors, deploy outlawed fission warheads, calibrate proximity fuses—all for a “show.”  If they really thought our goal was oases, they would have sent envoys to negotiate boundary lines, not pack sand with bombs and auto-rifles.  

3.  Debater A points to the thorn-barrier around the oases and the settlers’ talk about “mile-deep topsoil.”  Those are human constructions, human fears.  The Flap-jacks neither built the barrier nor comment on its purpose.  When Retief first sees the rampart, it’s described as “the Flap-jacks’ outer defensive line against Terry forays,” but we are never given a Flap-jack monologue about guarding soil.  Their own first explanations are all about providing “sport,” “contest,” “adequate show,” and limiting “atomics” for fairness in the ring.  

4.  Even Hoshick’s later allusion to “paradise-lichen” farming springs only after Retief—on behalf of the humans—suggests horsetrading combat for land.  Hoshick is surprised by the notion and only embraces it when he thinks landing a single-combat victory means Retief will cede the deserts.  Up to that point, he never once broaches agriculture or water rights as the human motive.  

5.  Debater A’s appeal to Passwyn’s sealed orders is irrelevant: those are Terran bureaucratic aims, not Flap-jack assumptions.  The question is what the Flap-jacks thought people (i.e. the Terrans) wanted.  Their texts are loud and clear: they assumed we wanted skirmishes—hence their obsession with recruiting more fighters, debating weaponry and staging ever grander battles.  

Conclusion  
At every turn the Flap-jacks frame us as sportsmen in search of combat, never as colonists in search of oases.  Their words—“sportsmen like ourselves,” “contest,” “adequate show,” “no atomics”—and their actions—arming for war-games, building warhead-screened skiffs, dispatching pickets purely to locate our positions—leave no doubt.  The correct answer is that the Flap-jacks thought people wanted skirmishes.

 "My apologies," said Retief. "The—ah—the skirmishform failed to  recognize that he was dealing with a sportsman."

 "Very well. Shall we begin?"

Retief rolled aside  as Hoshick turned on him; he jumped to his feet and threw a right  hay-maker to Hoshick's mid-section. The alien whipped his left fringe  around in an arc that connected with Retief's jaw, sent him spinning  onto his back ... and Hoshick's weight struck him. Retief twisted, tried to roll. The flat body of the alien blanketed  him. He worked an arm free, drumming blows on the leathery back.  Hoshick nestled closer.
